a Smoothing, summing, and standard deviations were performed using ArcGIS (ESRI, Redlands, CA) Focal Statistics in Spatial Analyst via arcpy in Python (Python Software Foundation version 2.7, www.python.org).
b Canopy and terrain heights estimated from lidar as described in Greaves et al (2017).
" Calculated from RGBN imagery via the 'raster' package (Hijmans 2015) in R (R Core Team 2017).
d Implemented using the Geomorphometry and Gradient Analysis Toolbox for ArcGIS (Evans et al 2014) via ArcPy in Python.
e Hue derived from RGBN imagery via ENVI (Exelis Visual Information Solutions, Boulder, Colorado).
f Raw intensity gridded using LAStools (Isenburg 2017).
" Implemented in SAGA GIS (Conrad et al 2015) via the 'RSAGA' package (Brenning 2008) in R.
were withheld from model building to be used as a test dataset; the remaining 75% of the plots :formula: were used to build the model. One model was built to predict all three footprints.
Because the Random Forest algorithm strives to produce the best overall accuracy, it is susceptible to producing poor accuracy for small classes in imbalanced datasets. Since our input dataset was imbalanced, we used an upsampling algorithm implemented in the caret package to ensure equal weighting of each class (Chen et al 2004). The model building was an iterative process: we used out-of-bag error rates and confusion matrices from early models to determine which classes could not be differentiated, then collapsed input classes accordingly (table S1 is available online at stacks.iop.org/ERC/1/105004/mmedia) and retrained the model, seeking a balance between accuracy and retention of informative classes. The final class names and reference plot membership counts are in table 3. We also used tools in the caret package to tune the number of trees and the number of variables selected for splitting at each tree node (mtry) based on 5-fold cross-validation repeated ten times. We found that any number of trees greater than 500 and any value of mtry less than approximately 6 gave largely similar results (data not shown). The final model used 1001 trees and an mtry of 1.
2.6. Mapping
After building the final Random Forest model, we applied it across the three data collection footprints using the AsciiGridPredict tool in the R package 'yaImpute' (Crookston and Finley 2007). Once the initial maps were built,

used to build the model. One model was built to predict all three footprints.
Because the Random Forest algorithm strives to produce the best overall accuracy, it is susceptible to
producing poor accuracy for small classes in imbalanced datasets. Since our input dataset was imbalanced, we
used an upsampling algorithm implemented in the caret package to ensure equal weighting of each class (Chen
et al 2004). The model building was an iterative process: we used out-of-bag error rates and confusion matrices
from early models to determine which classes could not be differentiated, then collapsed input classes
accordingly (table S1 is available online at stacks.iop.org/ERC/1/105004/mmedia) and retrained the model,
seeking a balance between accuracy and retention of informative classes. The final class names and reference plot
membership counts are in table 3. We also used tools in the caret package to tune the number of trees and the
number of variables selected for splitting at each tree node (mtry) based on 5-fold cross-validation repeated ten
times. We found that any number of trees greater than 500 and any value of mtry less than approximately 6 gave
largely similar results (data not shown). The final model used 1001 trees and an mtry of 1.

AsciiGridPredict tool in the R package 'yaImpute' (Crookston and Finley 2007). Once the initial maps were built,

Because the Random Forest algorithm strives to produce the best overall accuracy, it is susceptible to producing poor accuracy for small classes in imbalanced datasets. Since our input dataset was imbalanced, we used an upsampling algorithm implemented in the caret package to ensure equal weighting of each class (Chen et al 2004). The model building was an iterative process: we used out-of-bag error rates and confusion matrices from early models to determine which classes could not be differentiated, then collapsed input classes accordingly (table S1 is available online at stacks.iop.org/ERC/1/105004/mmedia) and retrained the model, seeking a balance between accuracy and retention of informative classes. The final class names and reference plot membership counts are in table 3. We also used tools in the caret package to tune the number of trees and the number of variables selected for splitting at each tree node (mtry) based on 5-fold cross-validation repeated ten times. We found that any number of trees greater than 500 and any value of mtry less than approximately 6 gave largely similar results (data not shown). The final model used 1001 trees and an mtry of 1.
2.6. Mapping

After building the final Random Forest model, we applied it across the three data collection footprints using the AsciiGridPredict tool in the R package 'yaImpute' (Crookston and Finley 2007). Once the initial maps were built,
